qas.question: What did Lilius first propose to correct in the calendar?
By how much is the Julian calendar too long?
How much difference does the extra 11 minutes make over 400 years time?
On what date was the original vernal equinox set?
By the time of Lilius where was the equinox falling?
Which year was eleven minutes too short?

plausible_answers.text: The mean tropical year is 365.24219 days long

qas.question: What causes an extra three days every 400 years in the Gregorian calendar?
What was originally set as March 25?

plausible_answers.text: deleting the Julian leap day on each of its ten occurrences over a period of forty years,

qas.question: What did Gregory propose deleting to correct the ten day drift?

context: <b5_0>Lilius's<b5_0/> proposals had two components. Firstly, he proposed a correction to the <a0_0>length of the year<a0_0/>. <b7_0>The mean tropical year is 365.24219 days long<b7_0/>. As the average length of a Julian year is 365.25 days, the <b6_0>Julian year<b6_0/> is almost <a1_0>11 minutes<a1_0/> longer than the mean tropical year. The discrepancy results in a drift of about <a2_0>three days<a2_0/> every 400 years. Lilius's proposal resulted in an average year of 365.2425 days (see Accuracy). At the time of Gregory's reform there had already been a drift of 10 days since the Council of Nicaea, resulting in the <b8_0>vernal equinox<b8_0/> falling on <a4_0>10 or 11 March<a4_0/> instead of the ecclesiastically fixed date of <a3_0>21 March<a3_0/>, and if unreformed it would drift further. Lilius proposed that the 10-day drift should be corrected by <b9_0>deleting the Julian leap day on each of its ten occurrences over a period of forty years,<b9_0/> thereby providing for a gradual return of the equinox to 21 March.
